In this work, we synthesized a series of Pd/ZrO2 catalysts inversely loaded with various metal oxide promoters (ZnO, In2O3, and CeO2), those would partially cover Pd metal surface and form some new metal-promoter interface, to explore the nature in the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The catalyst synthesized by this approach could limit the growth of Pd particles during the reduction and form new metal–metal oxide interfaces with different functions of CO2 hydrogenation, improving the reaction performance of Pd-ZrO2 catalysts. As a result, the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (12.0 %), methanol selectivity (95.6 %), and STY of methanol (472 gMeOHkgcat -1h−1), with excellent stability. The results of HRTEM, H2-TPR, XPS, and XAFS showed that the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had the typical Pd-ZnO interface with Pd2+ species after the H2 reduction, which could enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2. In addition, the in situ DRIFTS and NAP-XPS results implied that the Pd-ZnO interface significantly improved the formation of formate (HCOO*) and methoxy (H3CO*) species, which were considered to be the key intermediates of methanol generation, and thus greatly enhanced the selectivity of methanol. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Palladium Zinc oxide Zirconia Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The excessive emission of CO2 caused by the consumption of fossil fuels has led to a series of environmental problems, hence the capture and utilization of CO2 have become an active research field [1–5]. Currently, the main product of CO2 hydrogenation reactions could be CO, methane, some long-chain hydrocarbons, methanol, and other higher alcohols. Among these, methanol is not only considered as a potential alternative fuel, but also can be used as a platform chemical to produce other more valuable chemicals or fuels, such as formaldehyde, aromatics, and olefins [6–8]. Therefore, the reaction of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol has been extensively researched. So far, although this reaction can bring sound economic benefits, the low conversion and harsh thermodynamic operating conditions always reveal its limitations [9,10]. Moreover, Due to the active reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) and the excessive water in the CO2 hydrogenation, the employed catalysts usually have low methanol selectivity and are prone to deactivation [11–18]. During the development of the appropriate catalyst formulation, it was found that Palladium has a good activity of CO2 hydrogenation, and its selectivity is greatly affected by the oxide support and promoter [19], which are of great scientific interest. Among different oxide supports, ZrO2 is beneficial to the desorption of water in the reaction due to its weak hydrophilic character, hence avoiding the deactivation of the catalyst [20]. So far, in the research of Pd-based catalysts, metal oxides such as ZnO [21,22], In2O3 [23,24], and CeO2 [25,26] have been used as supports or promoters to improve the reaction performance. Malik et al. [27], found that the formation of PdZn alloys can enhance the catalytic performance and catalyst lifetime of PdZn/ZrO2 catalysts. Lee et al. [28,29], believed that Pd-ZnZrOx solid solution catalysts contain more oxygen vacancies, which help promote methanol production. On the one hand, the interaction between the active metal and oxide support and promoter can enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2, as well as the dissociation and subsequent spillover of H2 on Pd-based catalysts [27–30]. On the other hand, with the understanding of the hydrogenation active site and structure–function relationship, it is found that the metal-oxide interface can affect the reaction pathway and change the performance [33,34]. Significantly, on the inverse oxide/metal catalyst, it was found that the oxide partially covered the active metal could form the new metal-oxide interface structure, which could improve the performance of the catalyst [4,33,34]. In the meantime, this approach highlighted the crucial role played by the metal-oxide interface. The selectivity and stability of catalysts for methanol synthesis from CO2 still remain to be enhanced. Previous studies suggested that Pd-based catalyst has good activity in CO2 hydrogenation, but the reaction performance is greatly affected by the metal oxide support and promoter. In this work, we synthesized a series of Pd/ZrO2 catalysts inversely loaded with various metal oxide promoters (ZnO, In2O3, or CeO2), those would partially cover Pd metal surface and form the new metal-promoter interface, to enhance the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. In order to explore the effect of promoters on conversion and methanol selectivity of the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, we investigated the changes of the structure and function of the Pd-oxide interface on all promoted catalysts by HRTEM, H2-TPR, XPS, and XAFS. Moreover, in situ DRIFTS and NAP-XPS experiments were performed to clarify the reaction mechanism and the influence of the interface on the formation of intermediates during the CO2 hydrogenation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Material preparation Materials were Pd(NO3)2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 10 wt% in 10 wt% nitric acid, 99.999 % trace metals basis), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, 99.95 %), In(NO3)3·xH2O (Aladdin, 99.99 %), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Macklin, 99.95 %), and ZrO2 (Aladdin, 99.99 %). All Pd/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method. The metal loading of Pd for all samples was set at 3 wt%. Before the impregnation of zirconia with Pd, the zirconium dioxide was pre-calcined at 400℃ for 2 h. After that, the zirconium dioxide was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2 followed by drying in air at 120℃ for 12 h. Then, the sample was calcined at 400℃ for 2 h. The metal oxide promoters were added by the same impregnation method, drying, and calcination procedure. The loading of metal oxides (ZnO, In2O3, and CeO2) for all samples was set at 15 wt%. The resulting catalysts were denoted as M−Pd/ZrO2 (M = ZnO, In2O3, and CeO2). 2.2 Catalytic performance tests The catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation over Pd/ZrO2, ZnO-Pd/ZrO2, In2O3-Pd/ZrO2, and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 was evaluated in a fixed-bed micro-reactor equipped with a gas chromatograph. Typically, 0.5 g catalysts (20–40 mesh) were diluted with 1.0 g quartz particles (20–40 mesh) and then loaded inside the stainless-steel tubular reactor (ID 9.5 mm). Prior to the test, the catalyst was reduced at 300℃ for 2 h in pure H2 at a flow rate of 50 mL·min−1. After reduction, the feed flow was switched to a mixture of Ar, H2, and CO2 (Ar/H2/CO2 = 5/72/23). The catalyst was evaluated at 330℃, 3.0 MPa, and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 12000 h−1. All products were continuously collected and analyzed for the whole reaction (30 h). The product effluent gas was analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2014C gas chromatographs using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Using N2 as a carrier gas to monitor the H2, CO2, CO, and CH4 (No other gaseous products were formed). And the liquid products such as CH3OH and H2O were analyzed by a Porapak Q column. The CO2 conversion (X CO2) was defined as: X C O 2 % = CO 2 in - CO 2 out CO 2 in × 100 The selectivity (S i) was defined as: S C H 4 % = C H 4 out C H 4 out + C H 3 O H out + C O out × 100 S C H 3 O H % = C H 3 O H out C H 4 out + C H 3 O H out + C O out × 100 S CO % = C O out C H 4 out + C H 3 O H out + C O out × 100 The methanol space time yield (STY CH3OH) was defined as [32]: STY C H 3 O H % = X C O 2 × S C H 3 O H × CO 2 in Finally, catalyst powders after H2 reduction and CO2 hydrogenation would be collected for the following catalyst characterizations. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) results were obtained on a Rigaku Ultima IV with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The diffraction patterns were collected in the range of 2θ = 5°- 90° with the scan speed of 5°/min. Samples would be respectively analyzed after H2 reduction and after CO2 hydrogenation. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-F200 electron microscope. And energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS mapping) was performed on the same apparatus, operating at 200 kV. All samples of HRTEM were firstly dispersed into ethanol and sonicated for 20 min. Then a drop of the suspension was added to a copper grid with carbon and dried (operating in a glove box). H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. Before measurements, all samples were heated to 200℃ in He stream (20 mL/min) and maintained for 2 h to remove water or any other impurities. Then heating the pretreated catalysts from room temperature to 800℃ with the rate of 10℃/min under a mixture of 10 vol% H2 in Ar (50 mL/min). CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) results were obtained on a Quantachrome automated gas sorption analyzer. All reduced catalysts were firstly pretreated in H2 flow (30 mL/min) at 300℃ for 1 h and cooled to room temperature in N2 flow (20 mL/min). Then the samples were exposed to a CO2 stream (30 mL/min) for 30 min and purged by N2 (20 mL/min) for 2 h. Finally, the catalysts were heated from room temperature to 800℃ with the rate of 5℃/min under N2 flow (20 mL/min), and the desorbed CO2 would be monitored by a TCD. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on the Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray resource. Before experiments, all samples were reduced in situ in a H2 flow at 300℃ for 2 h in the catalytic chamber. After the reduction, samples were transferred to the analysis chamber under vacuum conditions for measurements. All electron binding energies (BE) referenced to the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. Data were analyzed using the Avantage software. All peaks would be fitted by Gaussian-Lorentzian curves after Shirley or Tougaard background subtraction. All fitted peaks were set with a Lorenz/Gaussian ratio of 30 %, a tail-mixing ratio of 100 %, and fixed tail heights and indices of 0. The automatic fitting algorithm selected was Powell, and the final fit was determined based on the minimal normalized chi-square and standard deviation. The fitting results, including the positions and areas of all fitted peaks, were directly outputted by the software. The Near Ambient Pressure (NAP) XPS measurements were carried out at the Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi, with a high-pressure reaction cell. The pressure in the analysis chamber was kept at 1.0 mbar. All reduced catalysts were pretreated in pure H2 at 300℃ for 1 h. Then it was cooled down to 50℃ in Ar and a mixture containing 25 % CO2 + 75 % H2 was fed to the analysis chamber. The temperature was increased from 50℃ up to 330℃ and maintained for 1 h at 50℃, 200℃ and 330℃ respectively. During this process, spectra were recorded at 50℃, 200℃, and 330℃. All heating ramps were performed at 10 ℃/min and temperature was controlled with a K-type thermocouple. The total gas flow was always 20 mL/min. Pd K-edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) spectra were recorded using a fluorescence yield collection technique on the beamline 1W1B of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF). Before the analysis at the beamline, samples were pressed into thin sheets 1 cm in diameter and sealed using Kapton tape film. The XAFS spectra were recorded at room temperature using a 4-channel Silicon Drift Detector (SDD) Bruker 5040. Negligible changes in the line shape and peak position of Pd K-edge XANES spectra were observed between two scans taken for a specific sample. Fourier transformation of the k3-weighted normalized extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data was carried over the range of 3.5 Å ≤ k ≤ 13.5 Å to obtain radial structure functions. Data analysis was performed using the Athena and Artemis software. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (in situ DRIFTS) experiments were carried out on a Thermo-Fisher Nicolet iS50 infrared spectrometer, equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid N2. Before the experiment, samples (15 mg) were placed in an in-frared cell with a ZnSe window and reduced in situ in 10 % H2/He at 300℃ for 2 h and then cooled down to room temperature under a helium stream. The background spectra were recorded in the N2 stream. The catalysts would be exposed to a CO2 stream for 30 min and flushed by a N2 stream for 1 h. And then, pure H2 was fed and the temperature was raised from 30 to 200℃ in intervals of 10℃. All spectra were recorded after 20 min in isothermal conditions at each temperature. The in situ CO-DRIFTS experiments were performed on the same apparatus. All reduced samples were exposed to carbon monoxide at 30℃ for 0.5 h and flushed by a N2 stream for 1 h. All spectra were obtained by collecting 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reaction performance The CO2 hydrogenation performance of all Pd-based catalysts was investigated at 330℃, 3.0 MPa via a fixed bed reactor. And the catalytic test results were shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . Clearly, the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst outperformed all other Pd-based catalysts, because of its highest CO2 conversion (12.0 %) and methanol selectivity (95.6 %). In Table S1, we compiled the catalytic performance of some reported catalysts under conditions similar to those in our works. It could be observed that the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 realized the highest STY of methanol (472 gMeOHkgcat -1h−1) compared to the catalysts listed in Table S1. On the other hand, the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had good methanol selectivity (94.7 %), but its CO2 conversion was not ideal (5.0 %). Significantly, when using these two catalysts, there were only traces of CO (≤0.01 %) formed during the reaction as listed in Table 1. Because the RWGS reaction and the methanol synthesis route occur simultaneously and competitively, high methanol selectivity usually results in low CO selectivity [37]. And the presence of ZnO and In2O3 also will help to inhibit the formation of CO [24,29]. In contrast, the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited good initial CO2 conversion (9.9 %) but rapid deactivation (4.7 % CO2 conversion at the last hour). More importantly, like the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had a major product of methane (60.5 %) rather than methanol (6.8 %), with the highest CO selectivity (32.7 %). Meanwhile, from Fig. 1, it appeared that all three catalysts had good stability except for the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. Based on the above results, it is considered that the introducing of ZnO and In2O3 onto Pd/ZrO2 would change the reaction route and greatly improve the ability of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. However, only the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited both excellent methanol selectivity and CO2 conversion with nice stability. The significant distinctions in the effects of various metal oxides may be related to the different interfaces between the Pd and these oxides. Thus, we aim to gain a deeper understanding of how these interfaces work by more characterizations. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 XRD patterns XRD was used to investigate the crystal structures of the reduced and spent catalyst, as shown in Fig. 2 . For the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, the diffraction peaks observed at 36.3°, 47.5°, and 62.8° were assigned to the (101), (102), (103) planes of ZnO (PDF#36–1451) respectively (Fig. 2A). And the diffraction peak located at 30.6° was ascribed to the (222) plane of In2O3 (PDF#06–0416) on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 sample. Significantly, no diffraction peak of the metal promoter or alloy phases could be observed [17,36]. It might indicate that the key species affecting the Pd/ZrO2 catalytic performances and changing the reaction route were these metal oxides rather than alloys. By contrast, the cerium and its oxide diffraction peaks couldn’t be observed due to the interference of the diffraction peaks of ZrO2 [39]. In addition, only the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the peak of the Pd (111) plane at 40.1° (PDF#06–0416). Hence, this catalyst might have the largest Pd particles, and it possessed worse dispersions of Pd than the other three catalysts. It was still not detected the metal promoters’ peaks on the XRD patterns of the spent samples (Fig. 2B), which indicated the stability of interactions between the Pd and these oxides. For the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, the little difference in XRD patterns on the reduced and spent samples indicated that the rapid deactivation during the initial stage of the reaction was irrelevant to the structural changes of the ZrO2. 3.2.2 TEM images TEM images and Pd particle size distributions of all reduced catalysts were shown in Figure S1 and Table 2 . It could be found that with the addition of In2O3 and CeO2, the size of Pd particles increased significantly. In contrast, the mean size of Pd particles on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was much smaller. In the meantime, the HAADF-STEM images and corresponding EDX elemental mappings verified the well-dispersed Pd element on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst (Figure S2). HRTEM images and lattice parameters of reduced catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 and Table 2. The interplanar spacing of 3.16 Å was attributed to the (−111) facet of ZrO2 (PDF#37–1484). Clearly, the ZrO2 (−111) lattice parameter of the unpromoted Pd/ZrO2 (Fig. 3A, 3.18 Å) and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 (Fig. 3B, 3.18 Å) was slightly larger than that of both In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 (Fig. 3C, 3.14 Å) and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 (Fig. 3D, 3.15 Å). It might be due to the incorporation of Pd2+ into the ZrO2 lattice on these two samples, resulting in the increase of the lattice spacing [32,40]. This phenomenon substantiates the strong interaction between Pd and ZrO2 on the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2. Therefore, some PdO was in the ZrO2 support lattice and not reduced during the H2 treatment [32]. Significantly, this strong Pd-ZrO2 interaction played a pivotal role in the stable hydrogenation, so both Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 exhibited higher conversions and good stability [41]. The ZrO2 (−111) lattice parameter on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 sample was the same as that of the Pd/ZrO2 sample, and the lattice distortion was detected in the contact region between Pd and ZnO (Fig. 3B), which was considered to prove the existence of the Pd-ZnO interface [4,12]. It was found that the Pd-ZnO interface facilitated the adsorption of CO2 and the activation of H2, and increased the consequent formation of methanol species [29–32]. Hence, the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had the highest CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. In contrast, it could be observed from the EDX elemental mappings that there were free In2O3, and some Pd particles were distributed on them (Figure S2C). The smaller ZrO2 (−111) interplanar spacing indicated that the addition of In2O3 promoted the reduction of Pd species, resulting in more Pd2+ being reduced to the Pd0 (Fig. 3C). However, the Pd-In2O3 interface formed on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was generally considered to have a high activity of methanol generation [14,23,24], so this catalyst exhibited a low conversion, but a high methanol selectivity. For the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, many CeO2 rods were observed covering the ZrO2 surface (Figure S1D), and the Pd species seemed to be connected more tightly with CeO2 than with ZrO2 (Fig. 3D). Therefore, we believed that the addition of CeO2 also increased the reducibility of Pd species and formed the Pd-CeO2 interface. This Pd-CeO2 interface caused the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst to exhibit similar performance to those Pd/CeO2 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation reaction, that was, low STY of methanol (Table S1) and rapid deactivation due to the formation of too much H2O during the reaction [41]. The morphology of the used samples did not obviously change as illustrated in Figures S3 and S4. Impressively, the size of Pd particles on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was basically unchanged after a long reaction, which indicated the satisfactory stability of the catalyst. 3.2.3 H2-TPR analyses H2-TPR was used to evaluate the reduction behavior of the freshly calcined catalysts. As shown in Figure S5, an inverse peak could be observed at 76℃ for all samples, which was due to the β-PdH species dissociated and released H2 [38,42]. Before this, PdO was reduced to Pd in the H2 atmosphere at room temperature. In addition, the intensity of the inverse peak indicated the amount of Pd species that could be directly reduced on the catalyst [38]. It was found that the inverse peak intensity of the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 samples was obviously lower than that of the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 samples. This was because the strong Pd-O interactions on the Pd-ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 caused some PdO species difficult to be reduced. This result actually was in good agreement with the larger ZrO2 (−111) lattice parameter of the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 samples in HRTEM, demonstrating that the addition of In2O3 and CeO2 improved the reducibility of Pd species. Only an inverse peak could be observed on the Pd/ZrO2 sample because ZrO2 support was hard to be reduced. For the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 sample, a peak can be observed at 450-500℃, which was attributed to the partial reduction of ZnO [30,32,42]. On the other hand, two H2 consumption peaks could be observed on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample at 300℃ and 650℃, corresponding to the reduction of surface CeO2 and bulk CeO2 respectively [25]. In contrast, the reducing behavior of the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 sample was much more complicated. Firstly, the peak near 200℃ was reported to arise from the formation of oxygen vacancies in the In2O3 [25,38,43]. After that, there were two reduction peaks could be observed at 300-400℃. The first peak (320℃) was attributed to the reduction of In2O3 and formed the InPd intermetallic with Pd0, while the second peak (390℃) corresponded to the further reaction after the formation of InPd, that is, the In2O3 was reduced to form the In3Pd2 intermetallic [38]. Finally, the high-temperature peak (507℃) was assigned to the reduction of bulk In2O3 on the catalyst [23]. 3.2.4 XPS XPS was performed to acquire information about the chemical states of surface Pd, O, and the promoters’ species in all catalysts. The Pd 3d deconvoluted spectra of the reduced catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 A, Table 3 and Table S2 (the Pd 3d 5/2 spectra were shown in Figure S7). Although the Zr 3p signal would interfere with the analyses of the Pd 3d signal, the peaks of Pd0 and Pd2+ could be distinguished at the Pd 3d5/2 binding energy of 335.2 and 336.6 eV on the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts [35]. These Pd2+ arose from the strong interaction between Pd and ZrO2 [40], which provided electrons to O and contributed to the adsorption and activation of CO2, so the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 had higher CO2 conversions. Meanwhile, the presence of this kind of Pd2+ species was consistent with the change of lattice in the TEM section. In contrast, only traces of Pd2+ could be observed on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts. Moreover, the higher binding energy of Pd0 species on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 and In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts suggested their lower electron cloud density [18,23], and it would lead to weaker hydrogenation activity, so more partial hydrogenation products, such as methanol, would form during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction [19,35]. On the contrary, the lower Pd0 binding energy of the Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts indicated that these two catalysts had the capacity for deep hydrogenation, resulting in higher methane selectivity. For the used ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts, the increasing ratio of Pd2+ species (Figure S7, Figure S8A and Table S1) was caused by the strong interaction between the newly formed oxygen vacancy and Pd species on the Pd-ZnO interface, and it is believed this interface property contributed to the efficient and stable reaction. Significantly, for the used CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, a new peak of Pd2+ could be observed at 337.2 eV, which was assigned to the Pd connected with the oxygen vacancy formed on CeO2 during the reaction [25]. The increasing oxygen vacancy concentrations on CeO2 would have a growing impact on Pd species, forming more Pd-CeO2 interface which showed lower CO2 hydrogenation activity than that of Pd-ZrO2, and would result in a decrease in the conversion. The O 1 s core level spectra of reduced catalysts were displayed in Fig. 4B and Table 3. Three peaks could be observed clearly after deconvolution. The peaks at about 529.8, 531.2, and 533.2 eV corresponded to the lattice oxygen (Olattice), the oxygen defects on the support (Odefect), and other weakly bound oxygen species (such as OH– or CO3 2–), respectively [25,29,32,44]. The B.E. value of oxygen vacancy species on Pd/ZrO2 and Zn-Pd/ZrO2 was lower than that of the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts (Table 3), which indicated that the oxygen electron cloud density of these two catalysts were higher, suggesting oxygen species got more electrons from Pd, and implying the stronger interactions between Pd and ZrO2. Impressively, there seem to be more oxygen defects on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts (Table 3), because both the H2 treated In2O3 and CeO2 oxides had high oxygen vacancy concentrations [23,24,26]. However, the excessive oxygen vacancy of In2O3 and CeO2 promoters caused the O in the bulk phase to migrate to the surface, making the PdO species easily reduced. Hence, the lack of Pd2+ could demonstrate the weakened function of the active site on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts, leading to poor reaction performance of these two catalysts. The O 1 s spectra of the spent samples were shown in Fig. S8B and Table S3. The growth of oxygen vacancy on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was the most striking. The newly generated oxygen vacancies ensured the stability of the Pd-ZnO interface, thus this catalyst was stable and efficient. However, the increase of oxygen vacancy concentration on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was also obvious. Combined with the change of the Ce chemical states (Figure S9), it was due to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ during the hydrogenation reaction, resulting in the formation of new oxygen defects on CeO2 [25]. These oxygen vacancies enhanced the Pd-O interaction on the Pd-CeO2 interface and even generated new Pd2+ species (Figure S8A). In order to investigate the evolution of the chemical states of Pd species during the CO2 hydrogenation, NAP-XPS experiments were performed on all Pd-ZrO2 catalysts. As shown in Figure S10, there was still an interference signal (the yellow line) ascribed to Zr 3p at about 333.3 eV in the Pd 3d deconvoluted spectra. The peak at about 335.2 eV was assigned to the Pd0 species of Pd 3d5/2, and the peak at 336.6 eV was attributed to the Pd2+ species [45–48]. In agreement with the previous XPS results, Pd2+ species existed in the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts at 50℃, and the area of the Pd2+ peak increased with increasing temperature (Figure S10A and B), due to the increasing Pd-O interaction on the interface which caused Pd to lose more electrons and thus generated more Pd2+ species. The presence of Pd2+ on the interface would contribute to the adsorption and activation of CO2 and could accelerate the hydrogenation reaction. In addition, the binding energy of Pd0 was high on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 and In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 samples, which is consistent with the results we observe in the XPS section. And as mentioned earlier, these low electron cloud density Pd0 species avoided the deep hydrogenation of CO2, which was favorable for the formation of methanol [19,35]. Therefore, the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst showed the highest CO2 conversion and methanol STY. Although only traces of Pd2+ species could be observed on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 sample, the binding energy of Pd0 (335.9 eV) was significantly higher than that of Pd/ZrO2, and would further increase with the increase of temperature (Figure S10C), contributing to a high selectivity of methanol [49,50]. However, the deficiency of Pd2+ on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst led to the insufficient function of the Pd active site, resulting in a poor ability to convert the adsorbed CO2. Impressively, for the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample (Figure S10D), not only the Pd2+ peak could be observed at 50℃, but also an additional Pd2+ species attributed to Pd-CeO2 was found at about 338.1 eV, implying that Pd had strong interactions with CeO2 and formed Pd2+ species at the beginning of the reaction [48]. Moreover, the binding energy of Pd2+ species decreased with the increased temperature could be attributed to the sintering of Pd particles [51], which was consistent with the results of TEM images and could be one of the reasons for the decline of the conversion of the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 at the initial reaction. 3.2.5 X-ray absorption spectroscopy We carried out the Palladium Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) measurements to discover the Pd coordination structure in all reduced catalysts. Fig. 5 A illustrated the Pd-K edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra for different Pd-ZrO2 samples, PdO, and Pd foil. It could be observed that XANES spectra of different Pd-ZrO2 resembled that of the reference Pd foil, which confirmed that the vast majority of PdO was reduced to metallic state on all catalysts under the reaction condition [22,24,29,31], as indicated by the H2-TPR results. Particularly, the intensity reduction of the rising edge of the Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 samples compared with the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 samples indicated the loss of electrons on Pd species, proving the Pd on their interface were more active [52]. In addition, the shift and drop of the white line peak suggested the existence of more PdO species on Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 samples [31,38], which could also imply their stronger Pd-O interaction, in agreement with the TEM and XPS results. The Pd k3-weighted EXAFS of all Pd-ZrO2 samples was shown in Fig. 5B, and the curve fitting results of EXAFS data were summarized in Table S4 and Figures S12-S13. The reduction of the Pd-O average coordination numbers (CNs) and the presence of Pd-O-M (M = Pd, Zn, In, and Ce) indicated that promoters affected the metal–metal oxide interfaces (Table S4) [10,24,53]. It has been reported that in Pd foil, the bond distance of Pd-Pd was 2.75 Å [22]. The Pd-Pd bond distance of In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 samples was both 2.75 Å, indicating that there was no Pd-In or Pd-Ce alloy on these two catalysts, because the existence of Pd-In and Pd-Ce would lead to the deviation of Pd-Pd bond distance [24,53]. This result implied that it was the metal oxide promoter rather than the alloy that improved the reducibility of Pd species on the catalyst. Impressively, the Pd-Pd bond length of the Pd/ZrO2 (2.76 Å) and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 (2.78 Å) samples was longer than that of Pd foil (2.75 Å). The Pd2+ in the lattice of ZrO2 support was close to Zr, so there were some Pd-Zr (2.85 Å) that would affect the Pd-Pd, leading to an increase in the Pd-Pd bond distance. In addition, the longer Pd-Pd bond of the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 sample (compared with that of Pd/ZrO2) suggested the stronger Pd-O interaction on the Pd-ZnO interface and more PdO species in the ZrO2 lattice. In the meantime, the stronger Pd-O interaction on the interface caused the greater pressure of the PdO by ZrO2 support, resulting in the compression of the Pd-O bond (1.98 Å) on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. As mentioned above, this strong Pd-O interaction was conducive to CO2 activation and H2 dissociation, which strongly contributed to accelerating the reaction rate [29,30]. 3.2.6 CO2-TPD The strength and quantity of surface basic sites of the reduced catalysts were characterized by CO2-TPD, as shown in Figure S6. The peak below 200℃ was attributed to the CO2 adsorbed at the weak basic site on the catalyst [30,40], which was generally considered as the physically adsorbed CO2 [32,54]. The wide peaks in the range of 400-500℃ were related to the CO2 adsorbed on the strong basic sites or the oxygen vacancy on the catalysts [30,32,40,55], and such sites could greatly influence the CO2 hydrogenation performance by affecting the adsorption and activation of CO2. In addition, these sites might encourage the formation of formate during the hydrogenation, which was considered to be the key intermediate for the formation of methanol [40]. It can be seen from Figure S6 that the addition of metal oxide promoters caused significant modifications in the strength and quantity of basic sites on the catalysts. Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had appreciable strong basic sites, indicating that the adsorption capacity of CO2 was strong, which was consistent with the observed high conversion in CO2 hydrogenation. For the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, it had a wider and higher-temperature peak, indicating that such sites became more and stronger. Therefore, the ability of CO2 adsorption of this catalyst was enhanced, and it showed a higher CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity [32,40]. For the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, the quantity of strong basic sites in the sample was significantly reduced, resulting in a weak CO2 adsorption capacity and a low CO2 conversion during the reaction. In contrast, the CO2-TPD curve of the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample had changed significantly, which had a high and sharp low-temperature peak and a weak and wide high-temperature peak. This curve was different from that of Pd/ZrO2 but was close to that of some Pd/CeO2 materials [54,56]. It insinuated that the addition of CeO2 may cause the excessive formation of the Pd-CeO2 interface on the reduced catalyst, which led to similar properties to the Pd/CeO2 instead of Pd/ZrO2. Hence, the tendency of the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst’s conversion was similar to that of these Pd/CeO2 catalysts, with an obvious decline at the initial stage of the reaction. 3.2.7 In situ DRIFTS To further investigate the microscopic structure and Pd dispersion of catalysts with different promoters, CO-DRIFTS were performed on all reduced Pd-ZrO2 catalysts. The reduced samples were exposed to CO at 30℃ for 0.5 h and flushed with pure N2 for 1 h. And all spectra were obtained at the same temperature. Fig. 6 showed the corresponding spectra, the bands at 2040, 1950, and 1880 cm−1 were assigned to the linear, bridged, and threefold CO adsorption on plane sites, respectively [16,21,25,40,53,57]. Obviously, with the addition of metal oxide promoters, the dispersion of Pd species was varied on ZrO2 support. The 3-fold and bridged CO adsorption on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had decreased, while the linear CO adsorption increased significantly, indicating that there were fewer large Pd clusters [16]. In addition, the bands of the adsorbed CO on Pd/ZrO2 and ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 samples (especially the threefold CO adsorption) shifted to higher wavenumbers significantly, suggesting the low Pd electron cloud density and strong Pd-O interaction, in agreement with the XPS and XAFS results presented above. In contrast, the most intense band assignable to the 3-fold CO adsorbed onto Pd sites could be observed on the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts, which originated from the larger Pd particle. Furthermore, compared with the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, the lower wavenumber of threefold CO adsorption on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst indicated its higher Pd electron cloud density and weaker hydrogenation capacity. It may cause the two catalysts to follow different reaction paths during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Hence, in situ DRIFTS studies were performed to identify the possible intermediates formed during the CO2 hydrogenation, thereby understanding the reaction mechanism. Firstly, all passivated samples were reduced in situ in 10 % H2/He at 300℃ for 2 h and cooled down to room temperature under pure He. Then, the catalysts would be exposed to CO2 for 30 min and flushed by pure N2 for 1 h. Next, pure H2 was fed and the temperature was raised from 30 to 200℃ in intervals of 10℃. All spectra were recorded after 20 min in isothermal conditions at each temperature. As shown in Fig. 7 , the strong peak at 1520 cm−1 was assigned to the C = O stretching vibration of carbonate (CO3 2–) species, and this species was generally formed after CO2 adsorption [32,33,40,54]. The peaks at 2898 and 2978 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching of the formate (HCOO*) C–H bond, and the peak at 1380 cm−1 was assigned to the C = O vibration of the HCOO* species [32,40,54,58,59]. In contrast, the methoxy (H3CO*) groups’ C–H stretching vibrations were found at 2846 and 2937 cm−1, and C-O vibration was found at 1060 cm−1 [32,33,54,59]. In addition, the peak at 1604 cm−1 was assigned to the adsorbed water [36,57], and the peak at 1697 cm−1 was attributed to the unstable COOH* intermediates which would lead to the formation of CO [58]. As shown in Fig. 7A, for the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, no H3CO* intermediate could be observed during the whole experiment, suggesting its poor methanol selectivity. In addition, the H2O band could be observed but no bands of formate and bicarbonate appeared on the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, indicating the Pd/ZrO2 should activate CO2 and generate methane through the direct C-O cleavage pathway [35,57]. The peaks of adsorbed HCOO* could be found on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst at 60℃ with the decrease of CO3 2– species, suggesting that the adsorbed CO2 had begun to hydrogenate to HCOO* intermediates at such a low temperature (Fig. 7B). Then, the peak of H3CO* was observed at 100℃ and was usually regarded as the result of HCOO* hydrogenation [32,59]. Hence, it can be concluded that methanol was produced through the hydrogenation of the CO3 2–, HCOO*, and H3CO* intermediates in sequence on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. Particularly, CO3 2– species completely disappeared at 140℃, which meant that the adsorbed CO2 was exhausted. After that, HCOO* and H3CO* species disappeared at 150℃ due to the conversion of these intermediates to CH3OH. Moreover, the rapid evolution of intermediates on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 sample implied a fast methanol generation rate, contributing to the highest methanol selectivity and STY. For the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 7C), H3CO* could be observed at a very low temperature (70℃) with a weak peak of HCOO*, which indicated that the rate of HCOO* → H3CO* on this catalyst was very rapid. And this step was considered to be the rate-determining step of the methanol generation [25,59], thus the methanol selectivity of the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was also excellent (94.7 %). However, the consumption of CO3 2– on this catalyst was slow, and there were still some residual CO3 2– species at 170℃, which implied that the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had an insufficient reaction activity of the adsorbed CO2, and resulting in a low CO2 conversion. Similar to the Pd/ZrO2 sample, no HCOO* or H3CO* peak could be observed on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 7D). Impressively, the peak of COOH* could be observed at 1697 cm−1, and it would lead to the formation of CO [58]. In addition, the formation of COOH* species proved that the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst generated methane and CO through a different pathway from the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, which was caused by its weaker hydrogenation capacity, in agreement with the XPS results. Moreover, it was found that the consumption of CO3 2– on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample was rapid with the increase of temperature, indicating that the adsorbed CO2 was reacting by H2 quickly, resulting in the highest initial conversion of this catalyst. 3.2.8 NAP-XPS NAP-XPS experiments were performed on all Pd-ZrO2 catalysts to identify and monitor the possible reaction intermediates during CO2 hydrogenation, as it can provide information in quasi-realistic conditions. The reduced samples were treated under a reaction mixture consisting of CO2 and H2 (CO2:H2 ratio 1:3) and the spectra were recorded at 50℃, 200℃, and 330℃. The C 1 s core level spectra of the reduced catalysts were summarized in Figure S11. However, the C–C signal (284.8 eV) was too strong to obtain information intuitively, so the detail of 285 eV- 291 eV in Figure S11 was shown in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8 the signal at 289.6 eV corresponded to the O-C = O of CO3 2– species and was associated with the adsorption of CO2 [60,61]. The signal of adsorbed CO could be found at 286.3 eV [45,62]. Significantly, the peaks at about 287.1 eV and 288.9 eV were assigned to H3CO* and HCOO* species, which were considered to be the key intermediates in the formation of methanol [45,62]. As shown in Fig. 8A, only the adsorbed CO2 and CO could be observed on the Pd/ZrO2 sample from 50℃ to 330℃, indicating that the main reaction on this catalyst was the CO2 methanation and the CH4 and CO products were mainly formed. For the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 8B), HCOO* and H3CO* species appeared at 50℃ after the reaction gas was injected. As mentioned in the in situ DRIFTS, the rapid and stable conversion of these two intermediates ensured the high methanol selectivity and reaction stability of the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. The absence of the CO3 2– signal indicated that the adsorbed CO2 had a fast hydrogenation rate, which would realize the high CO2 conversion of this catalyst. By contrast, the existence of CO3 2– and H3CO* in the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 sample at 50℃ and 200℃ (Fig. 8C) suggested that the rate of CO2 → HCOO* was insufficient, but the rate of HCOO* → H3CO* was rapid, those corresponded to the low conversion and high methanol selectivity of the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. The appearance of HCOO* peak at 330℃ proved that the rate of CO2 → HCOO* would increase with the increase of temperature, but the residual CO3 2– showed that the CO2 conversion of the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was lower than that of the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. The adsorbed CO could not be found on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample until 330℃ (Fig. 8D), which might be because the intermediate of hydrogenation on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst was the *COOH species instead of CO, hence CO could not be observed at the beginning of the reaction. It had once again proved that although the dominant products of the Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts were both methane and CO, they hydrogenated through different pathways as their active sites were Pd-ZrO2 and Pd-CeO2 interfaces, respectively. Impressively, with the increase in temperature, the binding energy of CO3 2– species kept growing (Fig. 8A, C, and D), which indicated that the electrons in O-C = O were shifted from C to O. The XPS results illustrated that the density of oxygen electron cloud decreased and the binding energy increased after the reaction. It led to the electron attraction of oxygen vacancy being enhanced during the reaction, and the electron of C of the CO2 adsorbed on the oxygen defects would shift to O, so the binding energy of O-C = O gradually increased. The O 1 s deconvoluted spectra were shown in Fig. 9 . The peak at about 529.3 eV was the lattice oxygen in the sample, and the peak at 532.1 eV was assigned to the CO3 2– species [63,64]. Peaks located at 532.4 and 531.2 eV were associated with HCOO* and H3CO* species, respectively [63,65]. Moreover, an additional signal at 530.8 eV was ascribed to OH– groups, which was usually associated with the formation of CH4 and CO during CO2 hydrogenation [63]. Intense OH* signal and weak CO3 2– signal could be observed on the Pd/ZrO2 sample (Fig. 9), thus it exhibited a high selectivity of methane and CO in the reaction. The binding energy of CO3 2– decreased with the increase in temperature, which was consistent with the increase of CO3 2– species binding energy in C 1 s spectra, proving the above speculation about electron transfer. The ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 sample always had the HCOO* and H3CO* signal at 50-330℃ (Fig. 9B), which again proved that more key intermediates for methanol generation would be formed on this catalyst during the reaction. In addition, the absence of OH– groups resulted in very little CH4 and CO formed during the reaction, realizing the highest methanol selectivity on the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. For the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 sample, the absence of HCOO* and the intense H3CO* peak suggested this catalyst could rapidly convert HCOO* into H3CO* (Fig. 9C). The maximum CO3 2– and OH* peaks were observed in Fig. 9D, indicating that the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst couldn’t generate the HCOO* or H3CO*, but formed intermediates conducive to CO2 methanation. Therefore, similar to the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, the product was mainly CH4 and CO. Moreover, the area ratio of OH* on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 sample was much higher than that of Pd/ZrO2, and excessive OH* species would lead to the further conversion of CO, resulting in catalyst deactivation [63]. 3.2.9 Discussions The Pd/ZrO2 catalysts inversely loaded with different metal oxide promoters (ZnO, In2O3, or CeO2) improved the methanol productivity. It was found that the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had the highest STY of methanol (472 gMeOHkgcat -1h−1) and CO2 conversion (12.0 %), with good stability during the 30 h reaction. Compared with the conventional promoted catalysts, the catalyst synthesized by this new approach could form new metal-promoter interfaces with different functions of CO2 hydrogenation, improving the reaction performance of Pd-ZrO2 catalysts. The typical Pd-ZnO interface and Pd2+ species were found on the reduced ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst in the HRTEM, H2-TPR, XPS, and XAFS. The strong Pd-O interaction resulted in more residual Pd2+ on the reduced catalysts, facilitating the activation and hydrogenation of CO2. And this interaction allowed the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 to exhibit a high conversion. Similarly, compared with the In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, more Pd2+ species were found on the unpromoted Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, which ensured its conversion (10.4 %). However, the in situ DRIFTS and NAP-XPS results implied that the Pd-ZnO interface could rapidly generate the formate and methoxy intermediates. Hence, the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had the highest selectivity and STY of methanol. In contrast, the Pd/ZrO2 catalyst lacked the active sites of the intermediates (the formate and methoxy) required for the generation of methanol, so it exhibited poor methanol selectivity (8.0 %). With the addition of In2O3, the Pd-In2O3 interface could be found on the reduced In2O3-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst (TEM, NAP-XPS), which was conducive to methanol production (in situ DRIFTS). Nevertheless, the Pd-ZrO2 interaction was weakened (the lack of Pd2+ species), resulting in high methanol selectivity (94.7 %) and low conversion (5.0 %). The addition of CeO2 led to many CeO2 rods covering the Pd/ZrO2 and formed the Pd-CeO2 interface with similar hydrogenation performances to some Pd/CeO2 catalysts (TEM, CO2-TPD), which exhibited rapid deactivation due to the H2O. Furthermore, in the in situ DRIFTS, only COOH* but not HCOO* was detected on the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2, which were favorable for the generation of CH4 and CO. And the results also proved that although the main products of the Pd/ZrO2 and CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts were both methane and CO, their reaction mechanisms were different. It was affected by the hydrogenation ability of Pd species on the Pd-ZrO2 (the direct C-O cleavage pathway) and Pd-CeO2 (the bicarbonate pathway) interface. The highest initial conversion might result in the formation of excess CO and H2O (NAP-XPS), leading to the deactivation of the CeO2-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst. 4 Conclusions We synthesized a series of Pd/ZrO2 catalysts inversely loaded with ZnO, In2O3, and CeO2 promoters. It was found that the strong Pd-O interaction resulted in more residual Pd2+ on the reduced ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalysts, facilitating the activation and hydrogenation of CO2, thus the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited a high CO2 conversion. Meanwhile, the Pd-ZnO interface could rapidly generate the formate and methoxy intermediates, therefore the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had the highest selectivity and STY of methanol. coredata.dc:description: The selectivity and stability of catalysts for methanol synthesis from CO2 still remain to be enhanced. In this work, we synthesized a series of Pd/ZrO2 catalysts inversely loaded with various metal oxide promoters (ZnO, In2O3, and CeO2), those would partially cover Pd metal surface and form some new metal-promoter interface, to explore the nature in the performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The catalyst synthesized by this approach could limit the growth of Pd particles during the reduction and form new metal–metal oxide interfaces with different functions of CO2 hydrogenation, improving the reaction performance of Pd-ZrO2 catalysts. As a result, the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (12.0 %), methanol selectivity (95.6 %), and STY of methanol (472 gMeOHkgcat -1h−1), with excellent stability. The results of HRTEM, H2-TPR, XPS, and XAFS showed that the ZnO-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst had the typical Pd-ZnO interface with Pd2+ species after the H2 reduction, which could enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2. In addition, the in situ DRIFTS and NAP-XPS results implied that the Pd-ZnO interface significantly improved the formation of formate (HCOO*) and methoxy (H3CO*) species, which were considered to be the key intermediates of methanol generation, and thus greatly enhanced the selectivity of methanol.
